I don't usually play through games twice, especially open world titles but Red Dead Redemption 2 remains one of the best games I've ever experienced. It was incredible back on the PS4 in 2018 and is still remarkable all these years later on PC. 

At 75% off in the recent sale, this was a fantastic purchase. It took me just over 35 hours to finish the main story once more, but in reality there is probably over 100 hours of original content here. The world is amazing, the story is thrilling all the way to the end and Arthur Morgan remains one of the most unforgettable protagonists in gaming history. 

Not a massive fan of the survival aspects like eating, hunting and tonics but those are easy to avoid if you want to skip some of the immersive additions. Money is a bit easy to come by also so things like robberies aren't really required. Fans of role playing may certainly get absorbed with all these extra gameplay features for a more realistic experience. 

The controls are extremely clunky and awkward at times though, especially indoors or trying to perform certain hold-button actions. Even with a gamepad, it can be rather cumbersome with a feel of input lag or general unresponsiveness. I didn't bother with the already-abandoned online portion of the game but that is another option to explore. 

Overall, this is an essential purchase especially for first time players and if you are itching to try it on PC after playing previous on console, it's definitely worth grabbing in the sale as it represents exceptional value for money at a discount.

Red Dead Redemption 2 is more than just a game—it's an experience that stays with you long after you've put down the controller. From the very first moment, the game pulls you into its beautifully crafted world, and the level of detail is nothing short of breathtaking.

The vibes are absolutely amazing. Riding through vast open landscapes as the sun sets, watching the light shimmer off a distant river, or camping under a sky full of stars — every moment in RDR2 feels alive and immersive. The world is rich with atmosphere, and Rockstar has outdone themselves in creating an environment that feels authentic and lived-in.

The story is deeply emotional and brilliantly paced, with characters that feel real, each with their own struggles and personalities. Arthur Morgan's journey is one of the best-written narratives I've experienced in gaming, and by the end, I felt genuinely connected to the characters and their world.

Beyond the story, simply existing in the game world is a joy. Hunting, fishing, playing poker in a dusty saloon, trying your luck at the blackjack tables (where you’ll probably lose more money than you make, but hey, that’s authenticity for you), or just wandering through a misty forest—the game rewards you for slowing down and soaking in the ambiance.

If you appreciate games that take their time and build a world that feels tangible, Red Dead Redemption 2 is a masterpiece. The visuals, the sound design, and the incredible attention to detail make this a must-play. It's not just a game; it's a work of art. 10/10.

RDR2 might be my favorite video game ever- no, favorite art piece ever. I'm not someone whose really into open world style games such as GTA or even western stuff, but this one has a special place in my heart.

At one of the lowest points in my life, and after many years of putting it off, I beat this game in its entirety twice. And i'm not kidding when I say this: this game genuinely changed my life and the way I view the world. Arthur Morgan is hands down one of the most relatable and most well written characters in fiction ever, and I oftentimes forget that he's not a real person in history.

Almost everything about this game, to its story and visuals, are gorgeous and breathtaking. I'm in love with the characters, the stories they tell, and my only wish is that Rockstar would focus on these characters and let us experience what its like to be them rather than milk their decade-old game's online mode. No other game has captivated me as much as this one, not even RDR1 (and I love that game too!) 

Obviously, the game itself is not without flaws (but like, what game isn't?) I'm admittedly not a fan of how the guns work compared to the first game. It feels like the focus was more on realism and that kinda tanked that aspect for me, especially the gun oil mechanic. And my #1 biggest complaint is still John's character model in the Epilogue (seriously, Rockstar??? WHY?) However, i'm willing to look past most of that simply because of just how beautiful the rest of the game is.

I can't believe I put this game off for so long all because I thought it was just gonna be "GTA with cowboys and horses." That cannot be further from the truth. That will forever be the biggest mistake I ever made. While I know RDR2 is popular, this is the only game I think deserves its high status. I don't usually say this, but this game is a genuine masterpiece, and it's the one game I think everyone (yes, everyone) should sit down and play though at least once in their life. It really did change my life for the better, as before I played this, I was not a great person admittedly, but this game taught me that to see good in the world, it all starts with you. I never thought a game about outlaw cowboys would be so emotional and make me cry. Arthur showed me what it truly means to live with "high honor." If I could give this game one central theme, it's "be the change you want to see in the world." 

I could go on and on, but instead of listening to me ramble about it, you should try it for yourself. It usually goes on sale for about $20, so if you can, please, just give this game a full play-through. It's well worth it, heck its even worth the $59.99 in my opinion.

Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)

Red Dead Redemption II is not just a game it’s an experience, a world so immersive and emotionally powerful that no other game has ever made me feel the way this one did emotionally. Set in 1899, at the tail end of the Wild West, it tells a gripping story of outlaws desperately trying to survive as the world around them changes. With god looking visuals, deep storytelling, and unparalleled attention to detail, this game is a masterpiece that defines what gaming as an art form can achieve in every parallel. I can say with confidence that this journey was worth every moment.

Story Mode
The game follows Arthur Morgan, a senior member of the Van der Linde gang, as he struggles with loyalty, morality, and survival in a world that is leaving outlaws behind. The writing is phenomenal, and Arthur’s development is one of the best character arcs in gaming history. His journey is emotional, tragic, and deeply personal, making you feel every triumph and heartbreak along the way, along with every change he makes. The relationships he forms with the gang, especially with Dutch, Hosea, John, and Sadie, feel incredibly well made, and watching the gang slowly unravel makes you feel desperate and sad. Few games have ever made me feel so connected to a character or so invested in their fate.

Open World
The open world of Red Dead Redemption II is unmatched in detail and beauty. From the snowy peaks of Ambarino and its big mountains to the swamps of Lemoyne and Saint Denis, the east country side of the New Hanover and the deserts of New Austin with now Tumbleweed being a real town and Armadillo rolling on the cholera, along with the magnificent West Elizabeth with Strawberry and Blackwater, every location is stunningly crafted and feels alive. The world reacts to you in ways no other game does, NPCs remember you for actions you did previously by helping or vice versa, animals have lifecycles and they can rot all day if you kill them, and random encounters can turn into meaningful little side stories. Riding through the vast landscapes as the sun sets, watching thunderstorms roll over the horizon, or simply camping under the stars makes every moment feel like a living, breathing Western film.

Music and Soundtrack
The soundtrack is pure magic. It captures the essence of the Wild West, with hauntingly beautiful melodies during quiet moments and intense, adrenaline pumping compositions during action scenes. Moments like "Unshaken" playing as Arthur returns to camp, or "That's the Way It Is" during one of the game’s most emotional scenes, are unforgettable. The music, combined with the atmospheric sounds of nature, bustling towns, and distant gunfire, makes the world feel truly alive.

Gameplay
The gameplay is methodical, immersive, and deeply rewarding. Gunfights are weighty and satisfying, enhanced by the iconic Dead Eye system. Horseback riding is the best in any game, making travel across the vast frontier a joy in itself. Hunting, fishing, and survival mechanics add to the realism, while side activities like poker, bounty hunting, and treasure hunting ensure there’s always something meaningful to do. The sheer depth of interactions, from greeting strangers to robbing them makes every playthrough feel unique.

Achievements
Completing every single achievement was a long but rewarding journey. From finishing the gripping main story and obtain 70 gold medals, to mastering challenges, collecting rare items, and fully exploring the world, each achievement felt like an accomplishment. The journey to 100% completion pushed me to experience every aspect of the game, and every second was worth it even though I've already played it on console.

Conclusion
Red Dead Redemption II is more than a game it’s an emotional journey that no other title has ever made me feel. It’s a story about loyalty, loss, and the end of an era of people who are getting kicked out, this game brought to life an unmatched level of detail and care. The world is stunning, the soundtrack is unforgettable, and Arthur Morgan’s journey is one of the greatest ever told in gaming, one of the greatest characters in video game history. Having completed every achievement, I can confidently say this is one of the best games ever made, and an experience that will stay with me forever in my life.

The is a lot of story characters, and all of them are written exceptionally well, something that is hard to believe when looking at the depth and background of all of the gang. Overall, Red Dead Redemption 2 is an experience everyone should try if they're interested, there's truly nothing like it.

The gameplay is great, with the best example of Rockstar’s polish and attention to detail to date. You probably already know what you’re getting into on that front, so I will just add that the immersiveness of all the gameplay elements work well in concert with the story and setting. It’s a full world and a joy to explore.

Even if you know how this story ends, the admittedly long trek there is well worth your time. RDR2 left more profound an impact on me than any game I have played. The game uses time and openness to great effect, placing the player firmly in the muddy boots of Arthur Morgan throughout a dynamic narrative. You can play the game like a thrill ride if you want, but it provides space to think if you are willing to take the time.

This contemplative quality was something new to me in a game. It showed that video games have at least one literary advantage over film: participation in the identity of the character.

Red Dead Redemption 2 is often celebrated as a masterpiece of storytelling and visual artistry, yet its ambitious design is not without notable flaws. While the game crafts an immersive and expansive depiction of the American frontier, certain gameplay decisions detract from the outlaw fantasy that many players long for.

Narrative and Gameplay Disparity
One of the most jarring design choices is the forced narrative transition, where players eventually have to adopt the perspective of another character. Early in the game, you are given the reins to embody a freewheeling outlaw—a role that is both empowering and deeply engaging. However, as the story unfolds, this mantle is unexpectedly passed on, stripping away not only your established identity but also tangible in-game assets such as your hard-earned horse. This loss is more than just a setback; it represents a significant break in the immersive experience, forcing players to reckon with the narrative's insistence on inevitability over player agency.

The Enigma of Hidden Cheats
Another point of contention lies in Rockstar's implementation of hidden cheats. Traditionally, cheat codes serve as a playful nod to player ingenuity, offering moments of liberation from the structured storyline. In Red Dead Redemption 2, however, these cheats are tucked away throughout the game world and remain inaccessible until a much later chapter. This delay raises an important question: what is the point of embedding these features if players are denied the opportunity to experience them during the early, more exploratory phases of the game? The inability to unlock these cheats when they might otherwise enhance the sense of freedom only reinforces the game’s overall narrative rigidity.

The Outlaw Versus Follower Dilemma
At its heart, the game aspires to offer an authentic outlaw experience, but its design often forces you into the role of a follower within a larger gang dynamic. For many, the appeal of being a lone renegade—unburdened by the dictates of a collective—forms the essence of the outlaw mythos. Instead, the game’s insistence on a shared journey dilutes this independence, leading to a feeling of frustration. This design choice suggests that the allure of the outlaw lifestyle is, in the end, secondary to the narrative’s demands for order and progression.

Conclusion
While Red Dead Redemption 2 dazzles with its rich world-building, deep character arcs, and intricate attention to detail, its gameplay mechanics betray a tension between artistic storytelling and player freedom. The enforced character transitions, the penalizing loss of key items, and the deliberately delayed access to hidden cheats collectively undermine the very spirit of rebellion and independence that defines the outlaw experience. In striving for a narrative that is as grand as it is cinematic, the game occasionally sacrifices the player's desire to live out a truly unbridled life on the frontier.

In summary, although Red Dead Redemption 2 is a technical and narrative triumph, its gameplay constraints serve as a reminder that even the most beautifully crafted worlds can feel restrictive when they do not fully embrace the player's role as a true lone outlaw.

Red Dead Redemption 2 isn’t just a game—it’s an experience. With one of the most immersive open worlds ever created, every town, mountain, and backroad feels alive, filled with dynamic NPCs, random encounters, and breathtaking landscapes. The story of Arthur Morgan is one of the best-written narratives in gaming, packed with emotional weight, moral dilemmas, and a slow-burning tension that builds to an unforgettable conclusion. Every detail, from the way Arthur’s clothes wear down over time to the realistic way horses react to danger, makes the world feel authentic.

It’s not a game that rushes you. The deliberate pace, from looting animations to the methodical gunplay, might not be for everyone, but it makes every moment feel meaningful. Whether you’re robbing a train, hunting in the mountains, or simply playing poker in a saloon, it’s easy to get lost in the sheer depth of what Rockstar has built. If you have the patience to embrace its world, RDR2 is easily one of the greatest games ever made.

Red Dead Redemption 2 is nothing short of a masterpiece that redefines the open-world genre. From the moment you step into the boots of Arthur Morgan, you are thrust into an incredibly rich narrative filled with complex characters, moral dilemmas, and breathtaking landscapes that feel alive.

Visuals and World Design

The graphics are absolutely stunning, showcasing Rockstar's dedication to immersive world building and detail. The world is meticulously crafted, from the bustling towns filled with life to the serene wilderness that invites exploration. Every sunrise and sunset paints the sky in vibrant colors, making each moment visually captivating. The attention to detail extends to the wildlife and ecosystems, creating a believable world where every animal behaves authentically.

Storytelling and Characters

The narrative is a poignant exploration of loyalty, family, and the harsh realities of life as an outlaw. Arthur Morgan's journey is beautifully written, with emotional depth that resonates throughout the game. The interactions with fellow gang members and strangers alike are crafted with care, making you genuinely invested in their fates. The game's pacing allows for quiet moments of reflection amidst intense action, creating a balanced experience that keeps you engaged.

Gameplay Mechanics

Gameplay is immersive and varied, offering everything from intense shootouts to peaceful fishing trips. The controls may feel heavy at times, but they contribute to a sense of realism that enhances immersion. The ability to interact with the environment—whether it's hunting for food or playing poker with locals—adds layers of depth to the experience. While some players may find the controls initially challenging, they become intuitive as you adapt to the game’s rhythm. 

Technical Performance

The game runs smoothly that is if you have a good enough hardware to run a masterful AAA game like this. 
The ability to tweak graphics settings allows you to optimize the experience according to your hardware capabilities. Experiencing the game on Vulkan API is top notch even with mods. While there may still be occasional minor issues, they do not detract significantly from the overall enjoyment.

Final Thoughts

In summary, Red Dead Redemption 2 is an unforgettable journey through a beautifully realized world filled with rich storytelling and engaging gameplay. It stands as a testament to what video games can achieve in terms of narrative depth and world-building.

I played this game around release and stopped playing because everything was too slow, the gameplay was okay, and I just don't like open world games all that much. But I came back to it after hearing a friend to treat it more like an immersive sim than a game (and that most gripes I had about the game aren't really present if I just do the main story). I started enjoying it much more when I did that. 

I spent most of my time in the game hanging out with the gang, doing the occasional side quest and mainly just focusing on the main story missions. I had fun hunting, playing mini games, hog tying a random NPC then throwing them on the train tracks and finding secrets, but it wasn't really enough to keep my attention. I only really wanted to know what was going to happen next in the story. 

The story is great, however, I started to notice a pattern with all of them. Go to Story mission, horse ride for a few minutes while talking to one of the characters, follow said character around and go to where the game points you where to go, kill a bunch of people, and then run away. That's not all of the story missions, but most of them follow that format. It sucked me out of the experience a few times because it became predictable, but I was enjoying the story for what it was (I will say it's mostly noticable in the final chapters of the game). There are a few moments that even got me to tear up, but not full on cry. I feel like those moments make the game more than worth giving a try.

Gameplay wise, it wasn't my favorite. Once I finished the main story, I went around just doing whatever I wanted to do. While I appreciate the amount of things you can do in this game and the different ways you can play, I didn't find myself doing a lot of it. Again, open world games just aren't my thing (but I so badly want to like them, so I keep on giving them a chance). There is a lot to do, but I wasn't interested in most of it.

The level of detail in this game is amazing and should be an example for the gaming industry. The world is well-designed; the nature and wildlife fit perfectly and interact with the characters and each other. For instance, I saw a hawk circle the ground and swoop down to grab a snake, or an owl capture a small creature at night. The game has so much to offer, with a massive world to explore and unique locations that sometimes lead to action or exploration.

The story was very engaging for me, and even on my second play-through, the characters stand out. The voice acting is solid, and the dialogue between characters is intriguing throughout the game. As the story progresses, the characters you started with change or reveal their true nature.

My only complaints about the story mode are that certain parts of the map are restricted until the end of the game, which annoys me in how it's implemented. Lawmen spawn out of nowhere, both in front of you and behind you, while invisible snipers shoot at you. This is unimpressive for a game that’s so detailed. The bounty system also doesn’t make much sense to me. For example, robbing a train without being recognized is impossible. Even with full disguise outfits, the law knows who you are right away. When robbing a train, the guards recognize you immediately, causing the bounty to start. Somehow, the law knows a train is being robbed in the middle of nowhere and arrives right away, leaving you with little to no time to loot the train. The combat is fun and simple to pick up, but the bounty system has flaws that hinder the experience. The game gives you multiple types of masks, but they don’t help much, as the law and guards recognize you instantly. The bounty starts rising quickly, making train robberies more of a net negative.

There’s not much to complain about in the rest of the story mode, but the multiplayer is a complete joke. It should never have been focused solely on making money online. The ridiculous prices in the online mode and locking items behind unreasonable levels are frustrating. The hackers are infesting the game, and they’re terrible trolls. It’s unplayable, and Rockstar developers have abandoned it because corporate greed led to a rushed and poorly thought-out online mode.

There could’ve been multiple paid DLCs that most players would’ve bought. The older game had a zombie mode with a short story—why can’t this one have something similar? It’s a missed opportunity for them to create both good content and a source of revenue at the same time.

A Cinematic Masterpiece of the Wild West Red Dead Redemption 2 is a monumental achievement in gaming, offering a deeply immersive and emotionally gripping experience set in the dying days of the Wild West. As Arthur Morgan, a member of the Van der Linde gang, you navigate a world of loyalty, betrayal, and survival.

The attention to detail is unparalleled, from the way Arthur’s beard grows to the interactions with NPCs. The story is rich and emotional, with complex characters and moral choices that impact the outcome.

The gameplay is a mix of shooting, horseback riding, and exploration, with a slow, deliberate pace that encourages you to soak in the world. The multiplayer mode, Red Dead Online, adds even more content, though it’s not without its flaws.

Pros:

Immersive World: A stunningly detailed and dynamic open world.

Emotional Story: A rich narrative with complex characters and moral choices.

Attention to Detail: Unmatched realism and immersion.

Cons:

Slow Pacing: The deliberate pace may not appeal to everyone.

Clunky Controls: Some mechanics can feel cumbersome.

Online Issues: Red Dead Online can feel grindy and lacks depth.

This is an imperfect masterpiece. In Rockstar's pursuit to surpass the quality of RDR, they worked so hard on adding detail and quality that it's biggest strength is also its biggest weakness. This game is the virtual embodiment of form over function.

[h2]The good...[/h2]

First of all; this game is gorgeous. Nobody will contest this. There's tons of vistas in this game that compel to take a second and enjoy the sights. RDR2 is overflowing with expensive detail; in fact, no other game, is so insanely chock full of "extra" than RDR2; the animated muscles on your steed, the countless unlikely scenarios that could possibly play out, the extreme complexity of an animal getting skinned, fluids correctly pouring from holes in containers and so on... Rockstar certainly went all in with this one. RDR2 is well over 6 years old and it's still one of the most gorgeous games ever created. Not only that but the engine is incredible! No modern AI up-sampling or frame generation needed, this is absolutely brilliant out of the box on 2018 hardware.

The story is good, but it's not as engaging as RDR's. Some of the best content is found in the side quests; my favorite encounter was that of a widow, living by a waterfall, north of Annesburg. She's mourning her husband, who died from wounds sustained during a bear attack. This storyline was very engaging and I honestly wished that this was three times longer and even more detailed. Another great series of side quests were those of the veteran, living by the lake not far from there. 

The hunting is one of the best parts of the game and I'm not usually into hunting games. Finding specific animals is at times frustrating, but this makes the gameplay loop all the satisfying. It's rare that a portion of game simulation seems so well put-together that it feels like scripted content; when I was hunting the legendary panther near Bolger Glade, he stalked and killed me so convincingly and cinematically that I was convinced it was a scripted sequence. Only to replay the encounter later to find that it was just procedural goodness. Hats off! The animal models are all extremely high level. The range of animations for each creature is so extensive, that I wonder how they got every asset to fit within the 120 gigabytes the game comes in. 

[h2]The bad...[/h2]

After extolling all the qualities RDR2 has to offer, it becomes clear where the tradeoff lies; this game isn't meant to be rushed. This is an experience that's meant to be absorbed through soulful rides at sunset, carefully inhaling every moment and not rushing by all of it like the busy city-folk we are. Rockstar wanted you to pause and to enjoy every second. 

That’s why every menu takes about a second to dismiss, every action is painfully detailed; skinning an animal takes quite a while and although it’s impeccably animated, after having seen it over a 100 times, you hope for that rare occasion where the skinning animation gets skipped entirely. A button press isn't good enough for RDR2, Rockstar prefers you to hold that button for a few seconds. I get that controllers only have so many buttons, but the amount of time I lost holding buttons in this game is ridiculous. I get the intention, but there's too much of it. Sure it feels real, but it's too slow, too much form, not enough function. 

During my entire playthrough I felt tremendously clumsy; your weapons getting unequipped every time you spend a few seconds on your horse, the way you right click to interact with a person, but you also right click to aim. So when a hogtied enemy is laying at your feet, it's very frustrating that your aim goes to that hogtied person instead of approaching enemies. It took too much time and a few modifications for me to get used to the controls. Even then they use entirely different standards for parts of the game, for instance in duels or with specific interactions during missions. They have so many separate control schemes for so many different situations, that it just feels clumsy. Again; form over function.

 This problem is most noticeable on horses. These are absolutely stunning, however with this level of detail, there's so much added grey area in which the horse doesn't know how to behave. The horse is constantly pulling against the player's commands. Which makes things feel more realistic, sure, but there's too many incidents inside that grey area; there’s just too many cases to list where your horse does something unexpected resulting in bodily damage. This is particularly infuriating when in a rush... Form over function. 

Another popular criticism about RDR2 is the inflexibility of its missions. And I certainly agree with this. There's one way to finish a mission and any other way will result in failure. I honestly wished the campaign was a lot less long and allowed for more flexibility.

[h2]and the disappointing...[/h2]

During my achievement hunt, I was quite enjoying the entire process. The only achievement I didn't really like was getting a gold rating in 70 missions. Many of the requirements for the gold stars were ambiguous and somewhat buggy, combine that with the long unskippable walking and talking sections and the whole experience can become disappointing.

I quite enjoyed good chunks of the story. I particularly liked Sadie's storyline, although I wished she maintained a little more grace toward the end of her arc. I think Arthur if fine, but I only liked him half as much as I liked John, both in RDR and RDR 2. His story is nicely rounded out, including his relationship with Abigail and his son Jack. My biggest problem with the story of RDR2 though is what you could call it's antagonist; Dutch. I don't like him at all. I know his character evolves during the story, but from the first moments of the game, I couldn't stand his attempt at leadership and wouldn't have followed him at all to be frank. His overzealousness was telegraphed too much and I was expecting quicker and more interesting conflict than what we got. Furthermore I think his appearance at the end of Marston's story in RDR 2 was entirely unnecessary and would have worked a lot better if they hadn't squeezed in this pointless cameo. 

I wasn't really disappointed all that much but I felt the chapters of my review worked well in this format. There's minor disappointments throughout the game, but nothing too intrusive. I had hoped there would have been more debauchery in this game, you can be mauled by a grizzly bear, eaten alive by a cougar, you can shoot a pedestrian in the face with a shotgun; however apart from the gore, everything feels sanitized. The brothels are just for show, and the most action you can get is a wash from a saloon attendant. I wouldn't necessarily expect prostitute visits to be included, but I would've added a bit more maturity in a game where your body count effectively means the pile of innocent bystanders you've accidentally run over with your horse. I felt it missing stuff like a cabaret with uncensored Cancan girls for instance or a random John fornicating with a lady of the night in an ally outside the saloon. There's a tiny bit of this, but I'd have appreciated a bit more of this. To paint the raw picture that is the Wild West rather than for voyeuristic reasons.

Related to this is the gambling mini games. I'd expected more. I wished there was a high rollers Poker table to be available somewhere. At a certain point you can find exactly that, but it's only a robbery activity, not a poker game you can participate in sadly. I would have liked to see a mini-game where you can bet on fights and such.

[h2]In the end[/h2]

First of all: It is a great game with lots of options how to play it. I really enjoy playing this game.

What does this game make so good?
- A really large map with regions with desert, mountains, swamp, plains and a lot in between. There is so much detail in the map (wildlife, plants, rivers, canyons etc.), that it is a great experience just to go (or ride) around the map descovering new details even after weeks of playing.

- The towns / cities are filled with life (domestic animals, NPC's, coaches, streetcars etc.) and look really realistic. You also find some dealers (general store, gun smith, doctor, saloon, stable etc.), that will sell you needed stuff as well as buy some raw materials from you (doctor, butcher, trapper). You also can buy horses or carts in the stable. 

- In addition, you find a trapper named Gus in some places within the wilderness (as well as in the largest town of St. Denis). He buy animal fur as well as full carcasses from you. If you bring these in perfect shape he will make clothes for you (you have to pay for it of course). This is a great additional to the "normal" clothes you can buy in the towns.

- You have a camp from where you can start exploring, stealing, hunting or else. This camp ist placed on the map when you start. You can relocate it into each region of the map just by using the defined order (relocation costs 2$). And you can improve the camp, depending on your experience level (and gold / money available).

There is so much in this game you can do or just leave it be, that writing all of it would take days (I think :-). 

But what I think is best in this game from my perspective: You have to make money as well as gold (legal or illegal ways are possible), to buy clothing, weapon, provisions etc. The second option to get "rich" might call rangers or even the cavalry upon you. But if you have enough gold with you, there are options to become a naturalist, bounty hunter, collector oder trader that offers you additional ways to make money, improve your camp etc.

I did not start the story mode, so I will add this experience to my review later on.
Have fun!
